{{Multiple issues|{{peacock|date=October 2018}}{{lead too long|date=October 2018}}}}
'''Michell structures''' are structures that are optimal based on the criteria defined by [[Anthony Michell|A.G.M. Michell]] in his seminal 1904 paper.<ref>[[Anthony Michell|Michell, A. G. M.]] (1904) ''The limits of economy of material in frame-structures'', Philosophical Magazine, Vol. 8(47), p. 589-597.</ref> [[Anthony Michell|Michell]] states that ''“a frame (today called truss) (is optimal) attains the limit of economy of material possible in any frame-structure under the same applied forces, if the space occupied by it can be subjected to an appropriate small deformation, such that the strains in all the bars of the frame are increased by equal fractions of their lengths, not less than the fractional change of length of any element of the space.”''
The above conclusion is based on the Maxwell load-path theorem:
<math>\sum_{} l_p f_p - \sum_{} l_q f_q = C</math>
Where <math>f_p</math> is the tension value in any tension element of length <math>l_p</math>, <math>f_q</math> is the compression value in any compression element of length <math>l_q</math> and <math>C</math> is a constant value which is based on external loads applied to the structure.
Based on the Maxwell load-path theorem, reducing load path of tension members <math>\textstyle \sum_{} l_p f_p</math> will reduce by the same value the load path of compression elements<math>\textstyle \sum_{} l_q f_q</math> for a given set of external loads. Structure with minimum load path is one having minimum compliance [[Topology_optimization#Structural_compliance|compliance]] (having minimum weighted deflection in the points of applied loads weighted by the values of these loads). In consequence Michell structures are minimum compliance trusses.
==Special cases==
'''1. All bars of a truss are subject to a load of the same sign (tension or compression).'''
Required volume of material is the same for all possible cases for a given set of loads. Michell defines minimum required volume of material to be: <math display="inline"> V_m=\frac{\sum_{} l f}{P}</math>
Where <math>P</math> is the allowable stress in the material.
'''2. Mixed tension and compression bars'''
More general case are frames which consist of bars that both before and after the appropriate deformation, form curves of orthogonal systems. A two-dimensional orthogonal system remains orthogonal after stretching one series of curves and compressing the other with equal strain if and only if the inclination between any two adjacent curves of the same series is constant throughout their length. This requirement results with the perpendicular series of cures to be either:
a) systems of tangents and [[involute]]s or
b) systems of intersecting [[logarithmic spiral]]s.
Note that straight line or a circle are special cases of a [[logarithmic spiral]].
==Examples==
Michell provided several examples of optimum frames:
{| style="border-spacing: 2px; border: 1px solid darkgray;" ! style="width: 120px;" | a ! style="width: 120px;" | b ! style="width: 120px;" | c ! style="width: 120px;" | d ! style="width: 120px;" | e |- style="text-align: center;" | [[File:MichellCantilever.jpg|240px|A single force F applied at A, and acting at right angle to the line AB]] | [[File:Michell centrally loaded in full space.jpg|240px|A single force F applied at C centered between supports at points A and B (full space solution)]] | [[File:Michell centrally loaded in half space.jpg|240px|A single force F applied at C centered between supports at points A and B (half space solution)]] | [[File:Michell centrally loaded in full space force away from line.jpg|240px|Centrally-loaded beam with force away from the straight line between supports AB. Construction similar to that of examples b and c]] |[[File:Torsion ball 3D cropped.gif|200x200px|Equal and opposite couples applied at points A, B on the straight line AB. The minimum frame consists of the series of rhumb-lines inclined at 45 deg to the meridians of the sphere having its poles at A and B]] |- style="text-align: center;" | A single force F applied at A, and acting at right angle to the line AB || A single force F applied at C centered between supports at points A and B (full space solution) || A single force F applied at C centered between supports at points A and B (half space solution) || Centrally-loaded beam with force away from the straight line between supports. Construction similar to that of examples b and c||Equal and opposite couples applied at points A, B on the straight line AB. The minimum frame consists of the series of rhumb-lines inclined at 45 deg to the meridians of the sphere having its poles at A and B |}
==Prager trusses== In recent years a lot of studies have been done on discrete optimum trusses.<ref>[[William Prager|Prager W.]], A Note on Discretized Michell Structures, Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering, Vol. 3, pp. 349-355, 1974</ref><ref>[[William Prager|Prager W.]] Optimal layout of cantilever trusses, Journal of Optimization Theory and Applications (1977) 23: 111. https://doi.org/10.1007/BF00932301</ref><ref>[[William Prager|Prager W.]] Nearly optimal design of trusses, Computers & Structures, ISSN: 0045-7949, Vol: 8, Issue: 3, Page: 451-454, 1978</ref> In spite of Michell trusses being defined for continuum (infinite number of members) these are sometimes called Michell trusses as well. Significant contribution to the topic of discrete optimum trusses had [[William Prager]] who used the method of the circle of relative displacements to arrive with optimal topology of such trusses (typically cantilevers). To recognize [[William Prager|Prager’s]] contribution discrete Michell trusses are sometimes called Prager trusses. Later geometry of cantilevered Prager trusses has been formalized by Mazurek, [[William F. Baker (engineer)|Baker]] and Tort <ref>Mazurek, A., [[William F. Baker (engineer)|Baker W.F.]] & Tort, C., Geometrical aspects of optimum truss like structures, Structural and Multidisciplinary Optimization (2011) 43: 231. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00158-010-0559-x</ref><ref>Mazurek, A., Geometrical aspects of optimum truss like structures for three-force problem, Structural and Multidisciplinary Optimization (2012) 45: 21. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00158-011-0679-y</ref> who noticed certain geometrical relationships between members of optimal discrete trusses for 3 point or 3 force problems.
[[File:Prager symmetrical truss.jpg|300px|An optimum discrete Prager truss for symmetrical cantilever.]]

{{about|the common change in machinery|the science fiction element|Resizing (fiction)}}
[[File:4 iPod Chargers.JPG|thumb|Battery chargers for successive generations of [[Apple Inc.|Apple's]] [[iPod]].]] '''Miniaturization''' ([[British English|Br.Eng.]]: ''Miniaturisation'') is the trend to manufacture ever smaller mechanical, optical and electronic products and devices. Examples include miniaturization of [[mobile phones]], [[computers]] and vehicle [[engine downsizing]]. In [[electronics]], [[Moore's law]], which was named after Intel co-founder [[Gordon Moore]],<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Nanoscience and Society|last=Guston|first=David|publisher=SAGE Publications|year=2010|isbn=9781412969871|location=Thousand Oaks, CA|pages=440}}</ref> predicted that the number of [[transistors]] on an [[integrated circuit]] for minimum component cos[[AkjsfbA,FKSNZS,;LFKJASD/;.FJAS;LDFKJUAOLSDFASF|t doubles every 18 months.]]<ref name="Moore1965paper">{{cite web|year=1965 |url=ftp://download.intel.com/museum/Moores_Law/Articles-Press_Releases/Gordon_Moore_1965_Article.pdf |title=Cramming more components onto integrated circuits |format=PDF |pages=4 |publisher=[[Electronics Magazine]] |accessdate=November 11, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080218224945/http://download.intel.com/museum/Moores_Law/Articles-Press_Releases/Gordon_Moore_1965_Article.pdf |archivedate=February 18, 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="IntelInterview">{{cite web|year=2005 |url=ftp://download.intel.com/museum/Moores_Law/Video-Transcripts/Excepts_A_Conversation_with_Gordon_Moore.pdf |title=Excerpts from A Conversation with Gordon Moore: Moore’s Law |format=PDF |pages=1 |publisher=[[Intel Corporation]] |accessdate=May 2, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029060050/http://download.intel.com/museum/Moores_Law/Video-Transcripts/Excepts_A_Conversation_with_Gordon_Moore.pdf |archivedate=October 29, 2012 |df= }}</ref> [[AkjsfbA,FKSNZS,;LFKJASD/;.FJAS;LDFKJUAOLSDFASF|This enables processors to be built in smaller sizes.]]
== History == The history of miniaturization is associated with the history of information technology based on the succession of switching devices, each smaller, faster, cheaper than its predecessor.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Nanostructuring Operations in Nanoscale Science and Engineering|last=Sharma|first=Karl|publisher=McGraw-Hill Companies Inc.|year=2010|isbn=9780071626095|location=New York|pages=16}}</ref> During the period referred to as the [[Second Industrial Revolution]], miniaturization was confined to two-dimensional electronic circuits used for the manipulation of information.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Introduction to Micromechanisms and Microactuators|last=Ghosh|first=Amitabha|last2=Corves|first2=Burkhard|publisher=Springer|year=2015|isbn=9788132221432|location=Heidelberg|pages=32}}</ref> This orientation is demonstrated in the use of vacuum tubes in the first general-purpose computers. The technology gave way to the transistor invented in the 1950s and then the integrated circuit approach developed afterward.<ref name=":0" />
Gordon Moore described the development of miniaturization in 1975 during the International Electron Devices meeting, where he confirmed his earlier prediction that silicon integrated circuit would dominate electronics, underscoring that during the period such circuits were already high-performance devices and starting to become cheaper. This was made possible by a reliable manufacturing process, which involved the fabrication in a batch process. It employed [[Photolithography|photolithographic]], mechanical, and chemical processing steps to create multiple Cheetos are the best chips in the world transistors on a single wafer of silicon.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Understanding Moore's Law: Four Decades of Innovation|last=Brock|first=David|last2=Moore|first2=Gordon|publisher=Chemical Heritage Press|year=2006|isbn=0941901416|location=Philadelphia, PA|pages=26}}</ref> The measure of this process was its yield, which is the ratio of working devices to those with defects and, given a satisfactory yield, a smaller transistor means that more can be on a single wafer, making each one cheaper to produce.<ref name=":4" />
== Development == Miniaturization became a trend in the last fifty years and came to cover not just electronic but also mechanical devices.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Science in Popular Culture: A Reference Guide|last=Van Riper|first=A. Bowdoin|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=2002|isbn=0313318220|location=Westport, CT|pages=193}}</ref> Today, electronic companies are producing silicon integrated circuits or chips with switching transistors that have feature size as small as 130 [[Nanometre|nanometers]] (nm) and development is also underway for chips that are merely few nanometers in size through the [[nanotechnology]] initiative.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Futuristic Materials|last=Jha|first=B.B|last2=Galgali|first2=R.K.|last3=Misra|first3=Vibhuti|publisher=Allied Publishers|year=2004|isbn=8177646168|location=New Delhi|pages=55}}</ref> The focus is to make components smaller to increase the number that can be integrated into a single wafer and this required critical innovations, which include increasing wafer size, the development of sophisticated metal connections between the chip's circuits, and improvement in the [[Polymer|polymers]] used for masks ([[Photoresist|photoresists]]) in the [[photolithography]] processes.<ref name=":3" /> These last two are the areas where miniaturization has moved into the nanometer range.<ref name=":3" />
Miniaturization in electronics is advancing rapidly due to the comparative ease in miniaturizing electrons, which are its principal moving parts. The process for mechanical devices, on the other hand, is more complex due to the way the structural properties of its parts change as they shrink.<ref name=":2" /> It is said that the so-called [[Digital Revolution|Third Industrial Revolution]] is based on economically viable technologies that can shrink three-dimensional objects.<ref name=":1" />

The ministry was formerly known as the National Research Affairs Ministry of the Republic of Indonesia. ==History== Founded in 1962 under the name National Research Affairs Ministry of the Republic of Indonesia, and in 1973 changed its name to the Ministry of Research. Year 1986-2001 as Minister of State for Research and Technology, and in 2002 according Circular Minister of State for Administrative Reform concerning Naming Government Agencies, Office of the Secretary of State referred to the Ministry of Research and Technology. In 2005 pursuant to Presidential Decree No. 9 In 2005, this institution called the Ministry of Research and Technology (KNRT) or as the State Ministry of Research and Technology. In 2009 pursuant to Presidential Decree 47 of 2009 referred to the Ministry of Research and Technology.{{cite web|url=http://www.ristek.go.id/index.php/module/Profile/id/2|title=Profile of Ministry of Research, Technology and Higher Education|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150314233705/http://ristek.go.id/index.php/module/Profile/id/2|archivedate=14 March 2015|df=dmy-all}} Logo of Ministry of Research, Technology and Higher Education (Indonesia).png|Logo of Ministry of Research and Technology (1978–2015) ==Function== {{Portal|Indonesia}} #Formulate and establish policies in the field of research and technology #Coordinate and synchronize policies in the field of research and technology #Manage of property/wealth of the country is the responsibility of the Ministry of Research and Technology #Oversight of the implementation of the tasks of the Ministry of Research and Technology In formulating the main directions and priorities of development of science and technology as well as the preparation of a strategic policy of national science and technology development, the Ministry of Research and Technology supported by the National Research Council (DRN). ==Organisation Structure== #Minister of Research, Technology and Higher Education #Secretary of State for Research and Technology #Institutional Deputy Science and Technology #Deputy Head of Resources Science and Technology #Deputy Science and Technology Network #Deputy Relevance and Productivity Science and Technology #Deputy of Administrative Science and Technology #Director General of Higher Education #Inspector General ==Coordination== Based on Presidential Decree No. 4 of 2003 on the co-ordination of formulation, Strategic Policy Development and Implementation of National Science and Technology, Ministry of Research, and Technology co-ordinate government agencies non-ministry as follows; {{More footnotes|date=December 2010}} [[File:Cape Canaveral Air Force Station.jpg|right|thumb|Cape Canaveral Missile Row in 1964]] '''Missile Row''' was a nickname given in the 1960s to the US Air Force and [[NASA]] launch complexes at [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]] (CCAFS). Operated by the [[45th Space Wing]] of the [[U.S. Air Force]] since 1949, it was the site of all pre-[[Apollo 8]] manned launches, as well as many other early [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] (DoD) and NASA launches. For the DoD, it plays a secondary role to [[Vandenberg AFB]] in [[California]], but is the launch site for many NASA unmanned [[space probe]]s, as those spacecraft are typically launched on [[United States Air Force|Air Force]] launchers. Active launch vehicles are in '''bold'''. Much of the support activity for CCAFS occurs at [[Patrick Air Force Base]] to the south, its reporting base. ==Inactive sites== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! width=125|Site ! Status ! {{unreferenced|date=March 2015}} '''Molinology''' (from [[Latin]]: molīna, mill; and [[Greek language|Greek]] λόγος, study) is the study of mills and other mechanical devices which use the energy of moving water or wind, or the strength of animal or human muscle to power machines for purposes such as [[hammer]]ing, [[Grinder (milling)|grinding]], [[pump]]ing, [[saw]]ing, [[Crusher|pressing]] or [[fulling]]. More particularly, molinology aims to retain the knowledge of those traditional engines which have been rendered obsolete by modern technical and economic trends.
The term "Molinology" was coined in 1965 by the Portuguese industrial historian João Miguel dos Santos Simões.
Cultural and scientific interest in molinology is maintained by [[The International Molinological Society]] (TIMS), a non-profit organisation which brings together around five hundred members worldwide. It was founded in 1973 after earlier international symposia in 1965 and 1969.
==See also== * [[Watermill]] * [[Tide mill]] * [[Windmill]] * [[Horse mill]] * [[Ship mill]] * [[Treadmill]] * [[Treadwheel]]
== Further reading == * {{cite book | first=M | last=Watts | authorlink= | year=2002 | title=The Archaeology of Mills and Milling | edition= | publisher=Tempus Publishing Ltd | location= | isbn=0-7524-1966-8 }} * {{cite book | first=D | last=Ogden | url=http://lccn.loc.gov/2011401534 |author2=G.Bost| year=2010 | title=The Quest for American Milling Secrets | edition=BM20 | publisher=TIMS Publication | location=Congleton, England | isbn=978-92-9134-025-5}}
==External links== *[http://www.molinology.org Official website of The International Molinological Society] *[http://www.spoom.org/ The Society for the Preservation of Old Mills (SPOOM)] *[http://www.millsarchive.com/ The Mills Archive]

{{Infobox company | type = Inc | name = Navizon, Inc | logo = [[Image:navizon.png|250px]] | foundation = 2005 | founder = [[Cyril Houri]] | location_city = [[Miami, FL]] | location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = '''[[Cyril Houri]]''', CEO| industry = [[Telecommunications]]| products = Navizon Virtual GPS, Navizon Indoor Triangulation System, Navizon Indoors | services = Location-Based Services & Positioning Technologies | homepage = {{url|www.navizon.com}} }} '''Navizon, Inc.''' is a provider of [[location-based service]]s and products. Navizon was an early developer of technology that makes it possible to determine the geographic position of a mobile device using as reference the location of [[cell phone tower]]s and [[Wi-Fi positioning system|Wi-Fi-based]] wireless [[Wireless access point|access points]] instead of [[GPS]]. Navizon also developed technology for locating mobile devices indoors with room and floor-level accuracy.
Navizon, initially known as Mexens Technology, was founded by a team from the Internet Protocol geolocation market. Its founder and CEO, [[Cyril Houri]], was founder and CEO of Infosplit, a provider of IP address geolocation services started in 1999 that was acquired in 2004.<ref>"Navizon". [http://www.crunchbase.com/company/mexens-technology "Mexens Technology"] ''CrunchBase''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>''Navizon''.[http://www.navizon.com/howitworks.php "Navizon: About, Company"]. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref>
==Global Positioning==
In 2005, Mexens Technology, as Navizon, Inc. was formerly named, introduced Navizon, a [[hybrid positioning system]] combining GPS, Wi-Fi and cellular positioning.<ref>Ryan Block (August 10, 2005). [https://www.engadget.com/2005/08/10/navizons-p2p-positioning-system "Navizon's P2P positioning system"]. ''Engadget''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Peter Cohen (July 10, 2007). [http://news.techworld.com/mobile-wireless/9427/navizon-offers-gps-without-satellites "Navizon offers GPS without satellites"]. ''TechWorld''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Publisher (July 12, 2007). [http://download.cnet.com/Navizon/3000-2064_4-10449433.html "Navizon for Windows Mobile"]. ''CNET''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Ben Wilson (February 8, 2008). [http://reviews.cnet.com/8301-19512_7-10115350-233.html "Navizon for iPhone gets live location tracking"]. ''CNET''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref> Mobile device users obtain their position through the Navizon app, which calculates the locations of [[cell site]]s and Wi-Fi access points by analyzing the signal strength at different locations. Navizon's database of cellular tower and Wi-Fi access point locations was built by a global community of users through [[crowdsourcing]].<ref>Mike Hudson (August 8, 2009). [http://www.mikesel.info/make-money-using-your-car-and-your-phone "Make money using your car and your phone!"]. ''MikeSel.info''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>[http://www.indoorlbs.com/2010/05/wi-fi-geolocation-navizon-crowd.html "Wi-Fi Geolocation - the Navizon Crowd-Sourcing Approach is a Proven Success"]. ''Indoor LBS''. (May 14, 2010). Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Zaib Kaleem (September 18, 2010). [http://wlanbook.com/incentivised-warcrowding-and-navizon-wifi-data-collection "Incentivised Warcrowding and Navizon WiFi Data Collection"]. ''Wlan book''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref>
The Navizon app also provides access to features such as Buddy Finder, which allows users to find the location of other registered users, and incentives through the Navizon Rewards System, which allows users to earn rewards for contributing data through Navizon's crowdsourcing initiative.<ref>Chris (January 3, 2009).[http://www.wpcentral.com/find-your-phone-navizons-mobfindr "Find your phone with Navizon's Mobfindr"]. ''WPcentral''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Ben Wilson (February 8, 2008). [http://reviews.cnet.com/8301-19512_7-10115350-233.html "Navizon for iPhone gets live location tracking"]. ''CNET''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>cwerdna (December 22, 2008). [http://priuschat.com/forums/freds-house-pancakes/56820-got-iphone-3g-now-you-can-paid-war-driver-find-access-points-cell-towers-w-navizon.html "got an iPhone 3G? now you can paid to be a war driver (find access points + cell towers) w/Navizon"]. ''Priuschat.com''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Chris Davies (June 17, 2011).[http://androidcommunity.com/navizon-crowd-sourced-android-mapping-app-pays-you-to-use-it-video-20110617/ "Navizon crowd-sourced Android mapping app pays you to use it (Video)]". ''Android Community'' Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Paul (January 3, 2008). [http://windows.modaco.com/topic/263615-cell-wifi-positioning-from-navizon-plus-make-money-on-the-move/page__p__867578#entry867578 " Cell + WiFi positioning from Navizon, plus make money on the move!"]. ''Windows at MoDaCo''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Anamika Singh (January 29, 2010). [http://iphone.tmcnet.com/topics/iphone/articles/74045-navizon-inc-announces-50-percent-increase-rewards-program.htm "IPhone -Navizon Inc. Announces 50 Percent Increase in Rewards Program Payout"]. ''TMCnet.com''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>[http://forum.xda-developers.com/showthread.php?t=681541 "Earn money with your phone through wifi and phone cell towers UK included"]. ''XDAdevelopers''. (May 14, 2010). Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Kevin C. Tofel (December 9, 2008). [http://gigaom.com/mobile/navigon-pays-yo/ "Navizon pays users to help build location database"]. ''GigaOm''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref>
Navizon's positioning products and services include the Navizon app, for individuals, and wireless positioning systems for corporations. In March 2009, the Navizon Wi-Fi positioning system was licensed by Yahoo Mobile and in March 2010 Microsoft selected Navizon for Wi-Fi and Cellular positioning.<ref>Justin (March 11, 2009). [http://gpsobsessed.com/yahoo-mobile-grabs-navizon-for-wi-fi-positioning/ "Yahoo Mobile grabs Navizon for Wi-Fi positioning"]. ''GPSobsessed''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Leena Rao (March 2, 2010). [https://techcrunch.com/2010/03/02/microsoft-taps-navizon-to-power-mobile-geolocation/ "Microsoft Taps Navizon To Power Mobile Geolocation"]. ''TechCrunch''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref>
==Locating devices indoors== In 2011, Navizon unveiled ''Indoor Triangulation System'' (I.T.S.), a location based service for businesses that tracks Wi-Fi enabled smart phones, tablets and notebooks, and gives a view of people traffic inside a building or throughout a campus with room-and floor-level accuracy.<ref>Davey Alba (October 27, 2011).[http://blog.laptopmag.com/navizons-new-location-technolog-lets-you-find-your-friends-indoors "Navizon’s New Location Technology Lets You Find Your Friends Indoors"]. ''LAPTOP''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Katherine Vong (October 30, 2011). [http://www.trendhunter.com/trends/navizon-indoor-triangulation-system "Friend-Finding Apps"]. ''TrendHunter''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref><ref>Nathesh (November 2, 2011).[http://m2m.tmcnet.com/topics/m2mevolution/articles/236788-navizon-debuts-new-indoor-triangulation-system.htm "Navizon Debuts New Indoor Triangulation System"]. ''TMCnet''. Retrieved 2011-12-04.</ref>
==Patents== In 2006, Mexens Technology, Inc. received United States Patent No. 7,397,424 for its “''System and Method for Enabling Continuous Geographic Location Estimation for Wireless Computing Devices''”.<ref>(July 8, 2008). '''Nelson rules''' are a method in [[process control]] of determining if some measured variable is out of control (unpredictable versus consistent). Rules, for detecting "out-of-control" or non-random conditions were first postulated by [[Walter A. Shewhart]] <ref>[http://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/pmc/section3/pmc32.htm Engineering Statistics Handbook 6.3.2], NIST/SEMATECH e-Handbook of Statistical Methods [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]], Dec 2006</ref> in the 1920s. The Nelson rules were first published in the October 1984 issue of the ''[[Journal of Quality Technology]]'' in an article by [[Lloyd S Nelson]].<ref>Lloyd S. Nelson, "The Shewhart Control Chart—Tests for Special Causes". Journal of Quality Technology 16, no. 4 (October 1984), 238-239. https://doi.org/10.1080/00224065.1984.11978921</ref>
The rules are applied to a [[control chart]] on which the magnitude of some [[Variable (mathematics)|variable]] is plotted against time. The rules are based on the [[mean]] value and the [[standard deviation]] of the samples.
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" ! Rule|| Description|| Chart Example|| Problem Indicated |- |width="75pt"| <center>Rule 1</center>||width="250pt"| One point is more than 3 standard deviations from the mean.|| [[File:Rule 1 - Control Charts for Nelson Rules.svg|256x192px|]]||width="250pt"| One sample (two shown in this case) is grossly out of control. |- | <center>Rule 2</center> || Nine (or more) points in a row are on the same side of the mean. || [[File:Rule 2 - Control Charts for Nelson Rules.svg|256x192px]]|| Some prolonged [[systematic bias|bias]] exists. |- | <center>Rule 3</center> || Six (or more) points in a row are continually increasing (or decreasing). ||[[File:Rule 3 - Control Charts for Nelson Rules.svg|256x192px]]|| A [[trend estimation|trend]] exists. |- | <center>Rule 4</center> || Fourteen (or more) points in a row alternate in direction, increasing then decreasing. ||[[File:Rule 4 - Control Charts for Nelson Rules.svg|256x192px|]]|| This much [[Oscillation (mathematics)|oscillation]] is beyond [[Signal noise|noise]].
Note that the rule is concerned with directionality only. The position of the mean and the size of the standard deviation have no bearing. |- | <center>Rule 5</center> || Two (or three) out of three points in a row are more than 2 standard deviations from the mean in the same direction. ||[[File:Rule 5 - Control Charts for Nelson Rules.svg|256x192px]]|| There is a medium tendency for samples to be mediumly out of control.
The side of the mean for the third point is unspecified. |- | <center>Rule 6</center> || Four (or five) out of five points in a row are more than 1 standard deviation from the mean in the same direction. ||[[File:Rule 6 - Control Charts for Nelson Rules.svg|256x192px]]|| There is a strong tendency for samples to be slightly out of control.
The side of the mean for the fifth point is unspecified. |- | <center>Rule 7</center> || Fifteen points in a row are all within 1 standard deviation of the mean on either side of the mean. ||[[File:Rule 7 - Control Charts for Nelson Rules.svg|256x192px]]|| With 1 standard deviation, greater variation would be expected.
|- | <center>Rule 8</center> || Eight points in a row exist, but none within 1 standard deviation of the mean, and the points are in both directions from the mean. ||[[File:Rule 8 - Control Charts for Nelson Rules.svg|256x192px |]]|| Jumping from above to below whilst missing the first standard deviation band is rarely random. |}
The above eight rules apply to a chart of a variable value.
A second chart, the moving [[Range (statistics)|range]] chart, can also be used but only with rules 1, 2, 3 and 4. Such a chart plots a graph of the maximum value - minimum value of '''N''' adjacent points against the time sample of the range.
An example moving range: if N = 3 and values are 1, 3, 5, 3, 3, 2, 4, 5 then the sets of adjacent points are (1,3,5) (3,5,3) (5,3,3) (3,3,2) (3,2,4) (2,4,5) resulting in moving range values of (5-1) (5-3) (5-3) (3-2) (4-2) (5-2) = 4, 2, 2, 1, 2, 3.
Applying these rules indicates when a potential "out of control" situation has arisen. However, there will always be some false alerts and the more rules applied the more will occur. For some processes, it may be beneficial to omit one or more rules. Equally there may be some missing alerts where some specific "out of control" situation is not detected. Empirically, the detection [[accuracy]] is good.

{{Politics}} The combination of '''politics and technology''' covers concepts, mechanisms, personalities, efforts, and [[social movement]]s including but not necessarily limited to the [[Internet]] and other [[Information technology|information and communication technologies]] (ICTs). A growing body of scholarship has begun to explore how Internet technologies are influencing [[political communication]] and [[Participation (decision making)|participation]], especially in terms of what is known as the [[public sphere]]. One of the most influential and transformational information and communication technologies is the [[mobile phone]] or [[smartphone]], which can include: talk, text messaging, [[Internet]] and [[World Wide Web|Web]] access, [[electronic mail]], [[faxing]], pictures, video, and a wide variety of [[Mobile app|apps]]. Mobile devices are proving to increase political participation and are now even being portrayed as a voting gadget in even the [[least developed countries]]. Increased availability of this [[technology]] and subsequent access to the public sphere has enhanced the ability of individuals and groups to bring attention to and organize around specialized issues.Creeber, Glen. Digital Cultures: [understanding New Media]. Maidenhead: Open Univ., 2009. Print. More recently, [[social media]] has emerged to become one of the main areas of influence for [[politics]], where millions of users are able to learn about politicians' policies and statements, interact with political leaders, organize, and voice their own opinions on political matters.{{cite book|title=Politics and the Twitter revolution : how tweets influence the relationship between political leaders and the public|last2=Bichard|first2=Shannon|date=2012|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=9780739165010|location=Lanham, MD|page=1|pages=|last1=Parmelee|first1=John}} == The digital public sphere == The idea of the [[public sphere]] has generally come to be understood as the open social spaces and [[public space]]s in which private citizens interact and share information and ideas relevant to the society. These can include, for example, town halls, public squares, markets, coffee shops, or what ancient Greeks called [[agora]]s. Many scholars have argued that these spaces are vitally important for creating and maintaining an active and informed public in a democratic society.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/24669015|title=Free spaces : the sources of democratic change in America|last=Evans|first=Sara M.|last2=Boyte|first2=Harry C.|date=1992|publisher=University of Chicago Press|others=|year=|isbn=978-0226222578|edition= 2nd|location=Chicago|pages=|oclc=24669015}} In [[Jürgen Habermas]]' book ''[[The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere|The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere – An Inquiry into a Category of Bourgeois Society]]'', he defines the public sphere as "a realm of social life in which public opinion can be formed."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/18327374|title=The structural transformation of the public sphere : an inquiry into a category of bourgeois society|last=Jürgen|first=Habermas|publisher=|year=1962|isbn=978-0262081801|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=|oclc=18327374}} In principle, the public sphere should be open to all citizens, and free from influence from governments or private businesses. Habermas goes on to argue that:
"A portion of the public sphere is constituted in every conversation in which private persons come together to form a public. They are then acting neither as business or professional people conducting their private affairs, nor as legal consociates subject to the legal regulations of a state bureaucracy and obligated to obedience. Citizens act as a public when they deal with matters of general interest without being subject to coercion; thus with the guarantee that they may assemble and unite freely, and express and publicize their opinions freely."
[[Howard Rheingold]] argues that, "There is an intimate connection between informal conversations, the kind that take place in communities... and the ability of large social groups to govern themselves without monarchs or dictators.”{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/44162557|title=The virtual community : homesteading on the electronic frontier|last=Howard.|first=Rheingold,|date=2000|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0262681216|edition= Rev. |location=Cambridge, Mass.|oclc=44162557}} Rheingold and others{{Cite journal|last=Dahlgren|first=Peter|date=2006|title=The Internet, Public Spheres, and Political Communication: Dispersion and Deliberation|journal=Political Communication|volume=22|issue=2|pages=147–162|doi=10.1080/10584600590933160}} have also gone on to argue that virtual spaces created through the [[Internet]] and related [[Information and communications technology|information and communications technologies]] have led to the emergence of a new type of digital public sphere. Some scholars have conceptualized this alternately as a virtual public sphere{{Cite journal|last=Papacharissi|first=Zizi|date=2002|title=The virtual sphere|journal=New Media & Society|language=en|volume=4|issue=1|pages=9–27|doi=10.1177/14614440222226244|issn=1461-4448}} or a networked public sphere,{{Cite journal|last=Shirky|first=Clay|date=2011|title=The Political Power of Social Media: Technology, the Public Sphere, and Political Change|jstor=25800379|journal=Foreign Affairs|volume=90|issue=1|pages=28–41}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/961312425|title=Twitter and tear gas : the power and fragility of networked protest|last=Zeynep|first=Tufekci|publisher=|year=2017|isbn=9780300215120|location=New Haven|pages=|oclc=961312425}} while still others have similarly described what they call a networked society{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/855022865|title=Communication power|last=Castells|first=Manuel|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2013|isbn=9780191510434|edition= 2nd|location=Oxford|pages=|oclc=855022865}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/795757037|title=Networks of outrage and hope: social movements in the Internet age|last=Castells|first=Manuel|date=|publisher=Polity|year=2015|isbn=9780745662855|edition= 2nd|location=Cambridge|pages=|oclc=795757037}} or networked publics.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/283798198|title=Networked Publics|last=Varnelis|first=Kazys|date=|publisher=MIT Press|others=Annenberg Center for Communication (University of Southern California)|year=2008|isbn=9780262285483|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=|oclc=283798198}} Essentially, these new virtual spaces can be used in much the same way as traditional, offline spaces; that is, as a "free space"{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/48943689|title=Democratic phoenix : reinventing political activism|last=Pippa|first=Norris|date=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=978-0521811774|location=Cambridge, UK|pages=|oclc=48943689}} to discuss and debate ideas of public importance. Just as the public sphere is a combination of "every conversation in which private persons come together to form a public" the digital public sphere also comprises all forms of [[new media]], such as [[chat room]]s, website comment sections, and [[social media]], in which private citizens engage in discourse as a public. Virtual spaces may overlap or interact with offline spaces as well, forming what has been called "hybrid networks".{{Cite journal|last=Lim|first=Merlyna|date=2015|title=A CyberUrban Space Odyssey: The Spatiality of Contemporary Social Movements|url=https://www.academia.edu/16240525|journal=New Geographies|language=en|volume=7|pages=117–123|via=}} Many scholars argue that social media affords increasing opportunities for political discourse and mobilization within the digital public sphere.{{Cite journal|last=Loader|first=Brian D.|last2=Mercea|first2=Dan|date=2011|title=Networking Democracy? Social media innovations and participatory politics|journal=Information, Communication & Society|volume=14|issue=6|pages=757–769|doi=10.1080/1369118X.2011.592648}} Research has shown that increased use of social media correlates with increases in certain types of political engagement and [[Participation (decision making)|participation]].{{Cite journal|last=Boulianne|first=Shelly|date=|year=2015|title=Social media use and participation: a meta-analysis of current research|journal=Information, Communication & Society|volume=18|issue=5|pages=524–538|doi=10.1080/1369118X.2015.1008542}}{{Cite journal|last=Kahne|first=Joseph|last2=Bowyer|first2=Benjamin|date=2018|title=The Political Significance of Social Media Activity and Social Networks|journal=Political Communication|volume=35|issue=3|pages=470-493|doi=10.1080/10584609.2018.1426662}} The digital public sphere thus has the potential to enliven democratic culture{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/227016731|title=Viral spiral : how the commoners built a digital republic of their own|last=David.|first=Bollier,|date=2008|publisher=New Press|isbn=978-1595583963|location=New York|oclc=227016731}} and enhance the ability of citizens to challenge the political and economic power of governments and corporations such as through online [[protest]]s, [[activism]] campaigns, and [[social movement]]s.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/639573767|title=Digitally enabled social change : activism in the Internet age|last=Earl|first=Jennifer|last2=Kimport|first2=Katrina|date=|publisher=MIT Press|others=|year=2011|isbn=9780262015103|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=|oclc=639573767}} Other scholars have also highlighted, alongside [[economic globalization]], the role of Internet technologies to reach across national borders to contribute to a growing transnational public sphere.{{Cite book|url=http://www.press.umich.edu/11707|title=Globalizations and Social Movements|date=2000|publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=9780472097210|editor-last=Guidry|editor-first=John|location=Ann Arbor, MI|language=en|doi=10.3998/mpub.11707|editor-last2=Kennedy|editor-first2=Michael|editor-last3=Zald|editor-first3=Mayer}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/51817597|title=Transnational activism in Asia : problems of power and democracy|last=Piper|first=Nicola|last2=Uhlin|first2=Anders|date=|publisher=Routledge|others=|year=2004|isbn=978-0415315135|location=London|pages=|oclc=51817597}} === Criticisms === ==== Social exclusion ==== The traditional, offline public sphere has been criticized for not being as inclusive in practice as it is in theory.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/23650367|title=Habermas and the public sphere|last=|first=|publisher=MIT Press|others=|year=1992|isbn=978-0262031837|editor-last=Calhoun|editor-first=Craig J.|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=|oclc=23650367}} For example, Feminist scholars like [[Nancy Fraser]] have argued that the public sphere has historically not been as open or accessible to [[Social exclusion|disadvantaged or marginalized groups]] in a society, such as women or people of color; therefore, such groups are forced to form their own separate public spheres, which she refers to as a [[Counterpublic|counter-public]] or ''subaltern counter public''.{{Cite journal|last=Fraser|first=Nancy|date=1990|title=Rethinking the Public Sphere: A Contribution to the Critique of Actually Existing Democracy|jstor=466240|journal=Social Text|issue=25/26|pages=56–80|doi=10.2307/466240}} Some scholars contend that online spaces are more open and thus may help to increase inclusive political participation from marginalized groups.{{Cite journal|last=Schlosberg|first=David|last2=Dryzek|first2=John S.|date=2002|title=Digital Democracy: Authentic or Virtual?|jstor=26162195|journal=Organization & Environment|volume=15|issue=3|pages=332–335}} In particular, [[Anonymity|anonymous]] online spaces should allow all individuals to speak with an equal voice to others.{{Cite journal|last=Deseriis|first=M.|date=2013|title=Is Anonymous a New Form of Luddism?: A Comparative Analysis of Industrial Machine Breaking, Computer Hacking, and Related Rhetorical Strategies|journal=Radical History Review|language=en|volume=2013|issue=117|pages=33–48|doi=10.1215/01636545-2210437|issn=0163-6545}} However, other have pointed out that many contemporary online spaces are not anonymous, such as [[Facebook]]. Avatars and social media profiles often portray an individual's offline identity, which can lead to practices of online discrimination and exclusion which mirror offline inequalities.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/214085023|title=Digitizing race : visual cultures of the Internet|last=Lisa|first=Nakamura|date=2008|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|year=|isbn=9780816653775|location=Minneapolis|pages=|oclc=214085023}} Now, more and more historically disadvantaged or marginalized groups are also using Internet technology to carve out new online spaces for their own "networked counterpublics" such as through the use of [[hashtag]]s like #Ferguson and [[Black Lives Matter|#BlackLivesMatter]].{{Cite journal|last=Jackson|first=Sarah J.|last2=Foucault Welles|first2=Brooke|date=2015|title=Hijacking #myNYPD: Social Media Dissent and Networked Counterpublics|journal=Journal of Communication|language=en|volume=65|issue=6|pages=932–952|doi=10.1111/jcom.12185|issn=0021-9916}}{{Cite journal|last=Jackson|first=Sarah J.|last2=Foucault Welles|first2=Brooke|date=2016|title=#Ferguson is everywhere: initiators in emerging counterpublic networks|journal=Information, Communication & Society|volume=19|issue=3|pages=397–418|doi=10.1080/1369118X.2015.1106571}} ==== The digital divide ==== Another factor which affects access to the digital public sphere is the [[digital divide]], which refers to how people from [[Least Developed Countries|less developed countries]] tend to have less access to [[Information and communications technology|information and communications technologies]] compared to those from more [[Developed country|developed countries]]. For example, the most developed regions of the world, such as North America and Western Europe, have the highest [[Global Internet usage|Internet penetration rates]] at over 80% each, while the least developed countries such as in Africa and South Asia have less than 30% each.{{Cite web|url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/269329/penetration-rate-of-the-internet-by-region/|title=Global regional internet penetration rate 2017 {{!}} Statistic|website=Statista|language=en|access-date=2018-07-01}} On the other hand, the reduced cost and increasing availability of mobile devices such as [[smartphone]]s throughout less developed regions is helping to reduce this disparity at an exponential rate. In just two years, between 2013 and 2015, the number of Internet users in developing nations has risen by 9%, according to the [[Pew Research Center]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.pewglobal.org/2016/02/22/smartphone-ownership-and-internet-usage-continues-to-climb-in-emerging-economies/|title=Smartphone Ownership and Internet Usage Continues to Climb in Emerging Economies|date=2016-02-22|work=Pew Research Center's Global Attitudes Project|access-date=2018-07-01|language=en-US}} Other research has shown, though, that even within more developed countries like the United States, the digital divide continues to persist between upper and lower socioeconomic classes{{Cite news|url=https://www.brookings.edu/research/broadband-adoption-rates-and-gaps-in-u-s-metropolitan-areas/|title=Broadband adoption rates and gaps in U.S. metropolitan areas|last=Tomer|first=Adie|date=2015|work=Brookings|access-date=2018-07-01|last2=Kane|first2=Jospeh|language=en-US}} and between different education levels.{{Cite news|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2018/03/05/some-americans-dont-use-the-internet-who-are-they/|title=11% of Americans don’t use the internet. Who are they?|date=2018-03-05|work=Pew Research Center|access-date=2018-07-01|language=en-US}} Furthermore, scholars like [[Mark Warschauer]] argue that it is not just access to technology that matters, but the knowledge of how to put that technology to use in meaningful ways.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/50028800|title=Technology and social inclusion : rethinking the digital divide|last=Mark.|first=Warschauer,|date=2003|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0262232241|location=Cambridge, Mass.|oclc=50028800}} == See also == * [[Cultural lag]] *[[Online deliberation]] * [[Media activism]] *[[Hashtag activism]] * [[Internet activism]] * [[Digital rights|Digital Rights]] * [[Netizen]] * [[Internet censorship]] * [[Neo-Luddism]] * [[Technocracy]] *[[Public hypersphere]] * [[Technology policy]] * [[E-democracy]] * [[E-government]] *[[Electronic voting]] * [[:Category:Regulation of technologies]] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Politics by issue|Technology]] [[Category:Technology in society]] [[Category:Politics and technology| ]]

'''Porting Authorization Code''' ('''PAC''') is a [[unique identifier]] (normally 9 characters long and in the format "ABC123456") used by some [[mobile network operators]] to facilitate [[mobile number portability]] (MNP). This allows users to retain their mobile telephone number when switching operators.
==United Kingdom== Telecommunications service is regulated in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] by [[Ofcom]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.btplc.com/Thegroup/RegulatoryandPublicaffairs/RegulationsintheUK/index.htm|title=Regulation in the UK|website=www.btplc.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-15}}</ref> On 25 July 2003, Ofcom introduced the ''General Conditions of Entitlement'' which apply to all communications networks and service providers in the UK. Several amendments to this original document have been issued since this time
Condition 18 requires all providers to provide number portability but only to subscribers of [[Publicly Available Telephone Services|publicly available telephone services]] who request it. Number portability must be provided as soon as practicable and on reasonable terms to subscribers and bilateral porting arrangements between providers must accord with agreed processes.
#A current Service Provider must give a customer a Porting Authorisation Code (PAC) or a reason why it cannot be issued within 2 working hours of their request (if for less than 26 numbers) or 10 working days (if 26+ numbers) #A PAC is valid for a period of 30 calendar days from the day of PAC issue and the customer's request must be submitted to their new Service Provider within that time. #A number can then be transferred anytime between 1 and 32 calendar days from the date the PAC is issued.
Some mobile phone companies can charge a fee to move the customer's number. This is usually no more than £25. The provider must issue a PAC within 2 hours of the port-out request, if such request was made over the phone for fewer than 25 numbers on a single account. Customer debt is not a valid reason for a service provider to refuse issuing of a PAC. Service providers may not treat PAC requests as requests to terminate service. Pay-as-you-go customers will lose any unused credit when switching service providers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.portnumber.co.uk/help#transfer-payg-credit|title=Port Number UK|website=www.portnumber.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref>
From 1st July 2019, customers will be able to request a PAC by text message, rather than having to call their existing network.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uswitch.com/mobiles/news/2017/12/uswitch-welcomes-ofcom-mobile-switching-plans/|title=Ofcom changes rules to allow switching network with single SMS|website=www.uswitch.com}}</ref>
==India==
In India, the code is known as a 'Unique Porting Code (UPC)'. The rules for number portability are prescribed by the [[TRAI|Telecom Regulatory Authority of India]].
*You are allowed to move to another mobile service provider only after 90 days of the date of activation of your mobile connection or from the date of last porting of your mobile number, whichever is applicable. *You are allowed to change mobile service provider across the country. *If you are a pre-paid subscriber, note that the balance amount of talk time, if any, at the time of porting will lapse. *If you are a post-paid subscriber, ensure that you have paid all the dues as per your last bill. (You will also have to sign an undertaking on the porting form.)
==See also== * [[Local number portability]] * [[Migration Authorisation Code]]

{{multiple issues| {{tone|date=January 2014}} {{advert|date=January 2014}} }} A '''professional network service''' (or, in an [[Internet]] context, simply '''professional network''') is a type of [[social network service]] that is focused solely on interactions and relationships of a business nature rather than including personal, nonbusiness interactions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB118825239984310205 |title=Social Networking Goes Professional |author=Jessica E. Vascellaro |publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=2007-08-28}}</ref>
A professional network service is used by business individuals to establish and maintain professional contacts<ref name='IJMR Article'>{{cite journal|url=https://www.mrs.org.uk/ijmr_article/article/104155|authors=Aichner, T. and Jacob, F.|title=Measuring the Degree of Corporate Social Media Use|journal=International Journal of Market Research|date=March 2015|volume=57|issue=2|pages=257–275}}</ref> and a way to either find work or get ahead in career as well as gain resources and opportunities for networking. According to LinkedIn managing director Clifford Rosenberg in an interview by AAP in 2010, "[t]his is really a call to action for professionals to re-address their use of social networks and begin to reap as many rewards from networking professionally as they do personally." Businesses mostly depend on resources and information outside company and in order to get what they need, they need to reach out and professionally network to others, such as employees or clients as well as potential opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/business/breaking-news/career-rewards-can-flow-from-social-media/story-e6freuyr-1225968705767 |title=Career rewards can flow from social media |author=AAP |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=2010-12-10}}</ref>
"Nardi, Whittaker and Schwarz (2002) point at three main tasks that they believe networkers need to attend in order to keep a successful professional (intentional) network: building a network, maintaining the network and activating selected contacts. They stress that networkers need to continue to add new contacts to their network in order to access as many resources as possible, and to maintain their network through staying in touch with their contacts. This is so that the contacts are easy to activate when the networker has work that needs to be done."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/226512/Professional_Networking_Online_A_qualitative_study_of_LinkedIn_use_in_Norway |title=Professional Networking Online: A qualitative study of LinkedIn use in Norway |author=Linda Elen Olsen |publisher=[[University of Bergen]]: Department of Information Science and Media Studies |date=May 2008}}</ref>
By using a professional network service, businesses are able to keep all of their networks up-to-date, in order, and help figure out the best way to efficiently get in touch with each of them. A service that can do all that helps relieve some of the stress when trying to get things done.
Not all professional network services are online sites that help promote a business. There are services that connect the user to other services that help promote the business other than online sites, such as phone/Internet companies that provide services and companies that specifically are designed to do all of the promoting, online and in person, for a business.
==History== In 1997, professional network services started up throughout the world and continue to grow. The first recognizable site to combine all features, such as create profiles, add friends, and search friends, was [[SixDegrees.com]]. According to Boyd and Ellison's article, "Social Network Sites: Definition, History, and Scholarship", "[f]rom 1997 to 2001, a number of community tools began supporting various combinations of profiles and publicly articulated Friends". Boyd and Ellison go on to say that the next wave began with [http://www.ryze.com Ryze.com] in 2001. It was introduced as a new way "to help people leverage their business networks".<ref>{{cite journal|title=Social Network Sites: Definition, History, and Scholarship |author1=Danah M. Boyd |author2=Nicole B. Ellison |publisher=Blackwell Publishing Inc |date=2007 |doi=10.1111/j.1083-6101.2007.00393.x |volume=13 |issue=1 |journal=Journal of Computer-Mediated Communication |pages=210–230}}</ref>
==Inside the works== Quite a lot of work is put into a professional network service, such as the amount of hours that go into them and the type of people they work for, as well as the business model of it all, such as the professional interaction and the multiple services they deal with.{{Citation needed|date=June 2015}}{{Vague|date=June 2015}}
===Types of services=== Some professional network services do not only help promote the business, but can also help in connecting to other people. Those services may include a specific phone and/or Internet company or a company that helps to connect with other businesses. According to the Society for New Communications Research (SNCR), there are at least nine online professional networks that are being used.
===Professional interaction=== Kaplan and Haenlein go on to discuss the five points about using media for companies. They say you need to choose carefully, pick the application or make your own, ensure activity alignment, integrate a media plan, and allow access for all.
====Choose carefully==== "Choosing the right medium for any given purpose depends on the target group to be reached and the message to be communicated. On one hand, each Social Media application usually attracts a certain group of people and firms should be active wherever their customers are present. On the other hand, there may be situations whereby certain features are necessary to ensure effective communication, and these features are only offered by one specific application."
====Ensure activity alignment==== "Sometimes you may decide to rely on various Social Media, or a set of different applications within the same group, in order to have the largest possible reach." "Using different contact channels can be a worthwhile and profitable strategy." According to the Society for New Communications Research at Harvard University "the average professional belongs to 3-5 online networks for business use, and LinkedIn, Facebook and Twitter are among the top used."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/fred.zimny/the-new-symbiosis-of-professional-networks-social-medias-impact-on-business-and-decision-making |title=The New Symbiosis of Professional Networks Survey Results |author1=[[Vanessa DiMauro]] |author2=Don Bulmer |publisher=Harvard University |pages=3 |date=2009-11-06}}</ref>
====Integrate a media plan==== Social media and traditional media are "both part of the same: your corporate image" in the customers' eyes.
====Allow access for all==== "...once the firm has decided to utilize Social Media applications, it is worth checking that all employees may actually access them." According to the SNCR "the convergence of Internet, mobile, and social media has taken significant shape as professionals rely on anywhere access to information, relationships and networks."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/fred.zimny/the-new-symbiosis-of-professional-networks-social-medias-impact-on-business-and-decision-making |title=The New Symbiosis of Professional Networks Survey Results |author1=[[Vanessa DiMauro]] |author2=Don Bulmer |publisher=Harvard University |pages=3 |date=2009-11-06}}</ref>
====Online usage==== "Half of respondents report participating in 3 to 5 online professional networks. Another three in ten participate in 6 or more professional networks." "Popular social networks are now being used frequently as Professional Communities. More than nine in ten respondents indicated that they use LinkedIn and half reported using Facebook. Twitter and blogs were frequently listed as 'professional networks'."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/fred.zimny/the-new-symbiosis-of-professional-networks-social-medias-impact-on-business-and-decision-making |title=The New Symbiosis of Professional Networks Survey Results |author1=[[Vanessa DiMauro]] |author2=Don Bulmer |publisher=Harvard University |pages=5, 6 |date=2009-11-06}}</ref>
===Business model=== According to [[Michael Rappa]]'s article, Business models on the web", "a [[business model]] is the method of doing business by which a company can sustain itself – that is, generate [[revenue]]. The business model spells-out how a company makes money by specifying where it is positioned in the [[value chain]]." Rappa mentions that there are at least nine basic categories in which a business model can be separated from. Those categories are [[brokerage]], [[advertising]], [[infomediary]], [[merchant]], [[manufacturer]], [[affiliate (commerce)|affiliate]], [[community]], [[subscription]], and [[utility]]. "...a firm may combine several different models as part of its overall Internet business strategy." At first, [[Flickr]] started off as a way to mainstream [[public relations]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Business models on the web |author=Michael Rappa |journal=North Carolina State University (ecommerce.ncsu.edu) |volume=13 |date=2000}}</ref>
==Social impact== When it comes to the social impact that professional network services have on today's society, it has proved to increase activity. According to the SNCR, "[t]hree quarters of respondents rely on professional networks to support business decisions. Reliance has increased for essentially all respondents over the past three years. Younger (20–35) and older professionals (55+) are more active users of social tools than middle aged professionals. There are more people collaborating outside their company wall than within their organizational intranet."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/fred.zimny/the-new-symbiosis-of-professional-networks-social-medias-impact-on-business-and-decision-making |title=The New Symbiosis of Professional Networks Survey Results |author1=Vanessa DiMauro |author2=Don Bulmer |publisher=Harvard University |pages=4 |date=2009-11-06}}</ref>
==Limitations== Since the internet and social media are a part of this "world where consumers can speak so freely with each other and businesses have increasingly less control over the information available about them in cyberspace", most firms and businesses are uncomfortable with all of the freedom. According to Kaplan and Haenlein's article, "Users of the world, unite! The challenges and opportunities of Social Media", businesses are pushed aside and are only able to sit back and watch as their customers publicly post comments, which may or may not be well written.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0007681309001232 |title=Users of the world, unite! The challenges and opportunities of Social Media |author1=Andreas M. Kaplan |author2=Michael Haenlein |journal=[[Business Horizons]] |date=2007-08-28 |doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2009.09.003 |volume=53 |issue=1 |pages=59–68}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Business networking]] *[[Social network service]] *[[List of social networking websites]] *[[Social media]] *[[OpenSkills|SkillsBase]] *[[User-generated content]] *[[Web 2.0]] *[[Social networking site]]s *[[Virtual world]]s

[[File:WAP Push Process.jpg|thumb|300px|WAP Push Process]] A '''Push Proxy Gateway''' is a component of [[Wireless Application Protocol|WAP]] Gateways that pushes URL notifications to mobile handsets. Notifications typically include [[Multimedia Messaging Service|MMS]], email, IM, ringtone downloads, and new device firmware notifications. Most notifications will have an audible alert to the user of the device. The notification will typically be a text string with a URL link. Note that only a notification is pushed to the device; the device must do something with the notification in order to download or view the content associated with it.
==Technical specifications== ===PUSH to PPG=== A push message is sent as an [[HTTP]] POST to the Push Proxy Gateway. The POST will be a multipart XML document, with the first part being the PAP (Push Access Protocol) Section and the second part being either a '''Service Indication''' or a '''Service Loading'''.<!--both currently redirect here, hence bold-->
+---------------------------------------------+ | HTTP POST | \ +---------------------------------------------+ | WAP | PAP XML | | PUSH +---------------------------------------------+ | Flow | Service Indication or Service Loading XML | / +---------------------------------------------+
====POST==== The POST contains at a minimum the URL being posted to (this is not standard across different PPG vendors), and the content type.
An example of a PPG POST: POST /somelocation HTTP/1.1 Host: ppg.somecarrier.com Content-Type: multipart/related; boundary=someboundarymesg; type="application/xml"
====PAP==== The PAP XML contains at the minimum, a <pap> element, a <push-message> element, and an <address> element.
An example of a PAP XML: --someboundarymesg Content-Type: application/xml
<?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE pap PUBLIC "-//WAPFORUM//DTD PAP 1.0//EN" "http://www.wapforum.org/DTD/pap_1.0.dtd"> <pap> <push-message push-id="some_push_id"> <address address-value="WAPPUSH=+12065551212/TYPE=PLMN@ppg.somecarrier.com" /> </push-message> </pap>
The important parts of this PAP message are the address value and type. The value is typically a [[MSISDN]] and type indicates whether to send to an MSISDN (typical case) or to an IP Address. The TYPE is almost always MSISDN as the Push Initiator (PI) will not typically have the Mobile Station's IP address - which is generally dynamic. In the case of IP Address: TYPE=USER@a.b.c.d
Additional capability of PAP can be found in the [[Push Access Protocol|PAP]] article.
====Service Indication==== A PUSH Service Indication (SI) contains at a minimum an <si> element and a <indication> element.
An example of a Service Indication: --someboundarymesg Content-Type: text/vnd.wap.si
<?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE si PUBLIC "-//WAPFORUM//DTD SI 1.0//EN" "http://www.wapforum.org/DTD/si.dtd"> <si> <indication si-id=345532 href="http://mmsc.somecarrier.com/CFJIOJF43F{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}"> A new MMS has been received, download? </indication> </si>
===PPG delivery to mobile station=== Once a push message is received from the Push Initiator, the PPG has two avenues for delivery. If the IP address of the Mobile Station is known to the PPG, the PPG can deliver directly to the mobile station over an IP bearer. This is known as "Connection Oriented Push". If the IP address of the mobile station is not known to the PPG, the PPG will deliver over an [[Short message service|SMS]] bearer. Delivery over an SMS bearer is known as "Connectionless Push".
====Connectionless Push==== In Connectionless Push, an [[Short Message Service Center|SMSC]] BIND is required for the PPG to deliver its push message to the mobile station. Typically, a PPG will have a local SMS queuing mechanism running locally that it BINDs to, and which in turn BINDs to the carrier's SMSC. This mechanism should allow for queuing in the event of an SMS infrastructure outage, and also provide for message throttling.
Since a WAP Push message can be larger than a single SMS message can contain, the push message may be broken up into multiple SMS messages, as a multipart SMS.
====Connection Oriented Push==== In Connection Oriented pushes (where the device supports it), an [[Short Message Service Center|SMSC]] BIND is not required if the gateway is aware of the handsets IP Address. If the gateway is unable to determine the IP Address of the handset, or is unable to connect to the device, the push notification will be encoded and sent as an [[Short message service|SMS]].
Connection Oriented Push is used less frequently than Connectionless Push for several reasons including: * Devices while registered to the network, may not have a data session (PDP Context in the GSM world) established. * A separate IP->MSISDN table has to be maintained in Connection Oriented Push. * Typically, the PPG or another part of the gateway has to receive [[RADIUS]] or other accounting packets in order to support Connection Oriented Push.
===Other PUSH Attributes=== * Push notifications can be confirmed or unconfirmed. Most carriers use unconfirmed pushes due to the high volume and resource constraints related to confirmed push. This is controlled by setting confirmed in the quality-of-service tag element. * Push notifications can be set to expire if not delivered before a certain time. This is controlled by setting deliver-before-timestamp in the pushmessage element.
Many other attributes exist and are detailed in the specifications at the [[Open Mobile Alliance]] and other sites.
==PPG Vendors== PPG vendors include [[Nokia Siemens Networks]], [[Ericsson]], [[Gemini Mobile Technologies]], [[Openwave]], [[Acision]], [[Huawei]], [http://www.azetti.com Azetti], Alcatel,[https://web.archive.org/web/20090813051635/http://www.wit-software.com/ WIT Software], ZTE, and open source [[Kannel (telecommunications)|Kannel]].
==See also== * [[PO-TCP]]
==References== *OMA WAP Specifications: **[http://www.openmobilealliance.org/tech/affiliates/wap/wap-251-pushmessage-20010322-a.pdf Push Message (Version 22, March 2001 - ref WAP-251-PushMessage-20010322-a)] **[http://www.openmobilealliance.org/tech/affiliates/wap/wap-167-serviceind-20010731-a.pdf Service Indication (Version 31, July 2001 - ref WAP-167-ServiceInd-20010731-a)] **[http://www.openmobilealliance.org/tech/affiliates/wap/wap-168-serviceload-20010731-a.pdf Service Loading (Version 31, July 2001 - ref WAP-168-ServiceLoad-20010731-a)]
